Crucial Concessions Made On Minimum Wage Bill Speaker J. Dennis Hastert offered crucial concessions to Democrats on a plan to raise the federal minimum wage, moving to end months of stalemate on a popular bill that Republicans feared could damage them at the polls.

The House and Senate earlier this year approved an increase in the minimum wage by $1, to $6.15 an hour, with the increase coming in 50-cent increments over two years in the House version and smaller annual amounts over three years in the Senate bill. [Page A1.]

Big Stock Gauges Approach Records Major stock market gauges crept close to records. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 60.21 points, or 0.5 percent, to 11,252.84. The gain put the blue-chip index less than 30 points from its April 11 high of 11,287.08. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index also neared a record, climbing 7.64 points, or 0.5 percent, to 1,514.09. Its peak of 1,527.46 was set on March 24. The Nasdaq composite index gained 27.91 points, or 0.7 percent, to 4,070.59. [C9.]

$4.5 Billion Deal for a Chip Maker Applied Micro Circuits, a semiconductor maker for networking equipment, has agreed to acquire MMC Networks, also a chip maker, in a stock swap valued at about $4.5 billion. The deal is part of Applied Micro's strategy to broaden its product line. Applied Micro shares closed at $183.81, down $4.75, in Nasdaq trading, while MMC shares jumped $31.75, to close at $110. [C6.]

Fen-Phen Settlement Is Approved A federal judge approved a national settlement that covers tens of thousands of people who took fen-phen, the diet drug combination that was sold by American Home Products. The settlement, which American Home has said would cost up to $3.75 billion, offers benefits depending on a person's injuries, ranging from refunds for the cost of the drugs to cash payments of more than $1 million to those who suffered the most. [C2.]

Rating on Loews Cineplex Lowered Reacting to an announcement from Loews Cineplex Entertainment that it might default on its debt, Standard & Poor's lowered its rating of the movie theater company's bonds to B from BB-. [C5.]

Spending Doubles Pace of Incomes Personal spending rose in July at twice the pace of incomes as consumers borrowed to make purchases and the savings rate fell to a record low, government figures showed. [C2.]

Rival Alliances in E-Book Software Stepping up the competition to define a standard format for electronic publishing, Microsoft and Adobe Systems both announced rival alliances intended to strengthen their respective positions in the growing market. [C8.]

Mitsubishi Shares Fall After Raid Shares of Mitsubishi Motors tumbled, as speculation mounted that its president would resign after the Tokyo police raided corporate headquarters. A spokesman for Mitsubishi Motors denied that the president, Katsuhiko Kawasoe, would resign to take responsibility for a scandal that erupted last week when the company admitted that it had covered up customer complaints and auto defects for more than two decades. [C4.]

Wachovia to Eliminate 1,800 Jobs Wachovia, one of the nation's largest banks, plans to cut about 1,800 jobs -- or about 8 percent of its work force -- as part of a sweeping revamping intended to reduce expenses by $100 million a year. [C2.]
